title: My Lab Journal
text: This is a template example for lab journaling. Students in the data science courses at the Institute of Entrepreneurship will use this template to learn R for business analytics. Students can replace this text as they wish.

title: My Lab Journal
text:
How to use

Accept the assignment and get your own github repo.
Blog/journal what you are doing in R, by editing the .qmd files.
See the links page for lots of helpful links on learning R.
Change everything to make it your own.
Make sure to render you website every time before you want to upload changes.

title: Statistical Concepts
text:
Note



You can delete everything in here and start fresh.



random_vars <- readRDS("C:/Users/sophi/OneDrive/Desktop/Causal Data Science for Business Analytics 2023/gitclone/cdsba-swynona/assets/Causal_Data_Science_Data/random_vars.rds")

expected_value_age <- mean(random_vars$age, na.rm = TRUE)
variance_age <- var(random_vars$age, na.rm = TRUE)
standard_deviation_age <- sd(random_vars$age, na.rm = TRUE)

print(paste('Expected Value Age = ', expected_value_age))

#> [1] "Expected Value Age =  33.471"

print(paste('Variance Age = ', variance_age))

#> [1] "Variance Age =  340.607766766767"

print(paste('Standard Deviation Age = ', standard_deviation_age))

#> [1] "Standard Deviation Age =  18.4555619466536"

expected_value_income <- mean(random_vars$income, na.rm = TRUE)
variance_income <- var(random_vars$income, na.rm = TRUE)
standard_deviation_income <- sd(random_vars$income, na.rm = TRUE)

print(paste('Expected Value Income = ', expected_value_income))

#> [1] "Expected Value Income =  3510.731"

print(paste('Variance Income = ', variance_income))

#> [1] "Variance Income =  8625645.84448348"

print(paste('Standard Deviation Income = ', standard_deviation_income))

#> [1] "Standard Deviation Income =  2936.94498492626"

covariance <- cov(random_vars$age, random_vars$income, use = "na.or.complete")
correlation <- cor(random_vars$age, random_vars$income, use = "na.or.complete")

print(paste('Covariance = ',covariance))

#> [1] "Covariance =  29700.1468458458"

print(paste('Correlation = ',correlation))

#> [1] "Correlation =  0.547943162326477"

E_income_age_less_18 <- mean(random_vars$income[random_vars$age <= 18], na.rm = TRUE)
E_income_age_18_65 <- mean(random_vars$income[random_vars$age >= 18 & random_vars$age <= 65], na.rm = TRUE)
E_income_age_greater_65 <- mean(random_vars$income[random_vars$age >= 65], na.rm = TRUE)

print(paste('Income less than Age 18 = ', E_income_age_less_18))

#> [1] "Income less than Age 18 =  389.607438016529"

print(paste('Income between Age 18 and Age 65 = ', E_income_age_18_65))

#> [1] "Income between Age 18 and Age 65 =  4691.3779637378"

print(paste('Income more than Age 65 = ', E_income_age_greater_65))

#> [1] "Income more than Age 65 =  1777.23728813559"

title: Causality
text:
Note



ok edit comment



library(ggplot2)

#> Warning: package 'ggplot2' was built under R version 4.2.3

library(dplyr)

#> Warning: package 'dplyr' was built under R version 4.2.3


#> 
#> Attaching package: 'dplyr'


#> The following objects are masked from 'package:stats':
#> 
#>     filter, lag


#> The following objects are masked from 'package:base':
#> 
#>     intersect, setdiff, setequal, union

df <- data.frame(
  Year = c(1996, 1997, 1998, 1999, 2000, 2001, 2002, 2003, 2004, 2005, 2006, 2007, 2008),
  MathDoctorates = c(1122, 1123, 1177, 1083, 1050, 1010, 919, 993, 1076, 1205, 1325, 1393, 1399),  # Replace with actual data
  UraniumStored = c(66.1, 65.9, 65.8, 58.3, 54.8, 55.6, 53.5, 45.6, 57.7, 64.7, 77.5, 81.2, 81.9)  # Replace with actual data
)
#DataSource
#https://tylervigen.com/spurious-correlations
#https://www.nsf.gov/statistics/infbrief/nsf11305/
#https://www.census.gov/compendia/statab/2012/tables/12s0937.pdf

ggplot(df, aes(x=Year)) +
  geom_line(aes(y=MathDoctorates, color="Math Doctorates")) +
  geom_line(aes(y=UraniumStored, color="Uranium Stored")) +
  scale_color_manual(values=c("Math Doctorates"="red", "Uranium Stored"="black")) +
  labs(title="Math doctorates awarded correlates with Uranium stored at US nuclear power plants",
       x="Year",
       y="Value",
       color="Legend") +
  theme_minimal()

title: Instrumental Variables

Note

title: Matching and Subclassification
text:
Note



ok, edit comment



#install.packages('MatchIt')
library(MatchIt)

#> Warning: package 'MatchIt' was built under R version 4.2.3

library(ggdag)

#> Warning: package 'ggdag' was built under R version 4.2.3


#> 
#> Attaching package: 'ggdag'


#> The following object is masked from 'package:stats':
#> 
#>     filter

library(dplyr)

#> Warning: package 'dplyr' was built under R version 4.2.3


#> 
#> Attaching package: 'dplyr'


#> The following objects are masked from 'package:stats':
#> 
#>     filter, lag


#> The following objects are masked from 'package:base':
#> 
#>     intersect, setdiff, setequal, union

library(ggplot2)

#> Warning: package 'ggplot2' was built under R version 4.2.3

#Load Data
data <- readRDS("C:/Users/sophi/OneDrive/Desktop/Causal Data Science for Business Analytics 2023/gitclone/cdsba-swynona/assets/Causal_Data_Science_Data/membership.rds")

# Compute correlations
correlations <- cor(data[, c("age", "sex", "pre_avg_purch", "card", "avg_purch")])

# Print correlations
print(correlations)

#>                      age          sex pre_avg_purch        card   avg_purch
#> age           1.00000000  0.012532675   0.517506430 0.105533628 0.448632638
#> sex           0.01253267  1.000000000  -0.001221386 0.008468092 0.002181853
#> pre_avg_purch 0.51750643 -0.001221386   1.000000000 0.192333327 0.855828507
#> card          0.10553363  0.008468092   0.192333327 1.000000000 0.382352233
#> avg_purch     0.44863264  0.002181853   0.855828507 0.382352233 1.000000000

# Define the DAG
dag <- dagify(avg_purch ~ card + age + sex + pre_avg_purch,
              card ~ age + sex + pre_avg_purch,
              exposure = "card",
              outcome = "avg_purch")

# Plot the DAG
ggdag(dag) + theme_dag()






#Native Estimate
treated <- data[data$card == 1,]
control <- data[data$card == 0,]
ATE_naive <- mean(treated$avg_purch) - mean(control$avg_purch)
print(paste("Naive ATE: ", ATE_naive))

#> [1] "Naive ATE:  25.2195043546585"

#(Coarsened)Exact Matching
match_exact <- matchit(card ~ age + sex + pre_avg_purch, data = data, method = "cem")
matched_data_exact <- match.data(match_exact)
ATE_exact <- with(matched_data_exact, mean(avg_purch[card == 1]) - mean(avg_purch[card == 0]))
print(paste("ATE after Exact Matching: ", ATE_exact))

#> [1] "ATE after Exact Matching:  24.3460918807853"

#Nearest Neighbor Matching
match_nn <- matchit(card ~ age + sex + pre_avg_purch, data = data, method = "nearest")
matched_data_nn <- match.data(match_nn)
ATE_nn <- with(matched_data_nn, mean(avg_purch[card == 1]) - mean(avg_purch[card == 0]))
print(paste("ATE after Nearest-Neighbor Matching: ", ATE_nn))

#> [1] "ATE after Nearest-Neighbor Matching:  17.4018004817322"

#Inverse Probability Weighting (IPW)
# (1) Propensity scores
model_prop <- glm(card ~ age + sex + pre_avg_purch,
                  data = data, # use 'data' instead of 'df'
                  family = binomial(link = "logit"))
summary(model_prop)

#> 
#> Call:
#> glm(formula = card ~ age + sex + pre_avg_purch, family = binomial(link = "logit"), 
#>     data = data)
#> 
#> Deviance Residuals: 
#>     Min       1Q   Median       3Q      Max  
#> -1.6229  -1.0439  -0.8521   1.2370   1.8271  
#> 
#> Coefficients:
#>                 Estimate Std. Error z value Pr(>|z|)    
#> (Intercept)   -1.4298676  0.0752043 -19.013   <2e-16 ***
#> age            0.0011486  0.0017761   0.647    0.518    
#> sex            0.0359388  0.0412622   0.871    0.384    
#> pre_avg_purch  0.0148262  0.0009264  16.003   <2e-16 ***
#> ---
#> Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1
#> 
#> (Dispersion parameter for binomial family taken to be 1)
#> 
#>     Null deviance: 13626  on 9999  degrees of freedom
#> Residual deviance: 13249  on 9996  degrees of freedom
#> AIC: 13257
#> 
#> Number of Fisher Scoring iterations: 4

# Add propensities to table
data_aug <- data %>% mutate(propensity = predict(model_prop, type = "response")) # use 'data' instead of 'df'

# Extend data by IPW scores
data_ipw <- data_aug %>% mutate(
  ipw = (card/propensity) + ((1-card) / (1-propensity)))

# Look at data with IPW scores
data_ipw %>% 
  select(card, age, sex, pre_avg_purch, propensity, ipw)



  


# (2) Estimation
model_ipw <- lm(avg_purch ~ card,
                data = data_ipw, # use 'data_ipw' instead of 'df_ipw'
                weights = ipw)
summary(model_ipw)

#> 
#> Call:
#> lm(formula = avg_purch ~ card, data = data_ipw, weights = ipw)
#> 
#> Weighted Residuals:
#>      Min       1Q   Median       3Q      Max 
#> -205.353  -28.995   -0.275   28.787  214.307 
#> 
#> Coefficients:
#>             Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)    
#> (Intercept)  70.2628     0.4320  162.66   <2e-16 ***
#> card         14.9573     0.6109   24.48   <2e-16 ***
#> ---
#> Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1
#> 
#> Residual standard error: 43.19 on 9998 degrees of freedom
#> Multiple R-squared:  0.05657,    Adjusted R-squared:  0.05647 
#> F-statistic: 599.5 on 1 and 9998 DF,  p-value: < 2.2e-16

# Plot histogram of estimated propensities
ggplot(data_aug, aes(x = propensity)) + # use 'data_aug' instead of 'df_aug'
  geom_histogram(alpha = .8, color = "white")

#> `stat_bin()` using `bins = 30`. Pick better value with `binwidth`.







# Run with high weights excluded
model_ipw_trim <- lm(avg_purch ~ card,
                     data = data_ipw %>% filter(propensity %>% between(0.15, 0.85)), # use 'data_ipw' instead of 'df_ipw'
                     weights = ipw)
summary(model_ipw_trim)

#> 
#> Call:
#> lm(formula = avg_purch ~ card, data = data_ipw %>% filter(propensity %>% 
#>     between(0.15, 0.85)), weights = ipw)
#> 
#> Weighted Residuals:
#>      Min       1Q   Median       3Q      Max 
#> -205.353  -28.995   -0.275   28.787  214.307 
#> 
#> Coefficients:
#>             Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)    
#> (Intercept)  70.2628     0.4320  162.66   <2e-16 ***
#> card         14.9573     0.6109   24.48   <2e-16 ***
#> ---
#> Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1
#> 
#> Residual standard error: 43.19 on 9998 degrees of freedom
#> Multiple R-squared:  0.05657,    Adjusted R-squared:  0.05647 
#> F-statistic: 599.5 on 1 and 9998 DF,  p-value: < 2.2e-16

title: Directed Acyclic Graphs
text:
Note



ok edit commetn



#install.packages("ggdag")
library(ggdag)

#> Warning: package 'ggdag' was built under R version 4.2.3


#> 
#> Attaching package: 'ggdag'


#> The following object is masked from 'package:stats':
#> 
#>     filter

library(dplyr)

#> Warning: package 'dplyr' was built under R version 4.2.3


#> 
#> Attaching package: 'dplyr'


#> The following objects are masked from 'package:stats':
#> 
#>     filter, lag


#> The following objects are masked from 'package:base':
#> 
#>     intersect, setdiff, setequal, union

library(ggplot2)

#> Warning: package 'ggplot2' was built under R version 4.2.3

# Your data
store_data <- data.frame(
  Store = c("A", "B", "C", "D"),
  y0 = c(135, 121, NA, NA),
  y1 = c(NA, NA, 102, 94),
  d = c(0, 0, 1, 1),
  y = c(135, 121, 102, 94),
  ITE = c(NA, NA ,NA ,NA)
)

# Create a DAG
dag <- dagify(y ~ d + y0 + y1,
              d ~ y0,
              y0 ~ ITE,
              y1 ~ ITE,
              exposure = "d",
              outcome = "y",
              latent = c("ITE"),
              coords = list(x = c(ITE = 1, y0 = 2, d = 3, y1 = 4, y = 5),
                            y = c(ITE = 2, y0 = 1, d = 2, y1 = 1, y = 2)))

# Plot the DAG
ggdag(dag) 






# Load the data
data <- readRDS("C:/Users/sophi/OneDrive/Desktop/Causal Data Science for Business Analytics 2023/gitclone/cdsba-swynona/assets/Causal_Data_Science_Data/customer_sat.rds")

# View the structure of the data
str(data)

#> tibble [15 × 3] (S3: tbl_df/tbl/data.frame)
#>  $ follow_ups  : num [1:15] 8 7 8 9 10 6 7 6 8 8 ...
#>  $ satisfaction: num [1:15] 40 45 47 44 50 55 60 62 59 65 ...
#>  $ subscription: chr [1:15] "Elite" "Elite" "Elite" "Elite" ...

model1 <- lm(satisfaction ~ follow_ups, data = data)
summary(model1)

#> 
#> Call:
#> lm(formula = satisfaction ~ follow_ups, data = data)
#> 
#> Residuals:
#>     Min      1Q  Median      3Q     Max 
#> -12.412  -5.257   1.733   4.506  12.588 
#> 
#> Coefficients:
#>             Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)    
#> (Intercept)  78.8860     4.2717  18.467 1.04e-10 ***
#> follow_ups   -3.3093     0.6618  -5.001 0.000243 ***
#> ---
#> Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1
#> 
#> Residual standard error: 7.923 on 13 degrees of freedom
#> Multiple R-squared:  0.658,  Adjusted R-squared:  0.6316 
#> F-statistic: 25.01 on 1 and 13 DF,  p-value: 0.0002427

model2 <- lm(satisfaction ~ follow_ups + subscription, data = data)
summary(model2)

#> 
#> Call:
#> lm(formula = satisfaction ~ follow_ups + subscription, data = data)
#> 
#> Residuals:
#>     Min      1Q  Median      3Q     Max 
#> -4.3222 -2.1972  0.3167  2.2667  3.9944 
#> 
#> Coefficients:
#>                      Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)    
#> (Intercept)           26.7667     6.6804   4.007  0.00206 ** 
#> follow_ups             2.1944     0.7795   2.815  0.01682 *  
#> subscriptionPremium   44.7222     5.6213   7.956 6.88e-06 ***
#> subscriptionPremium+  18.0722     2.1659   8.344 4.37e-06 ***
#> ---
#> Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1
#> 
#> Residual standard error: 2.958 on 11 degrees of freedom
#> Multiple R-squared:  0.9597, Adjusted R-squared:  0.9487 
#> F-statistic: 87.21 on 3 and 11 DF,  p-value: 5.956e-08

ggplot(data, aes(x = follow_ups, y = satisfaction)) +
  geom_point() +
  facet_wrap(~subscription) +
  geom_smooth(method = "lm", se = FALSE, color = "red") +
  labs(title = "Relationship between Follow-ups and Satisfaction",
       x = "Follow-ups",
       y = "Satisfaction")

#> `geom_smooth()` using formula = 'y ~ x'

title: Randomized Controlled Trials
text:
Note



ok edit comment



library(ggplot2)

#> Warning: package 'ggplot2' was built under R version 4.2.3

# Load the data
# Replace 'path_to_your_file' with the actual path to your .rds file
data <- readRDS('C:/Users/sophi/OneDrive/Desktop/Causal Data Science for Business Analytics 2023/gitclone/cdsba-swynona/assets/Causal_Data_Science_Data/abtest_online.rds')

# Check whether the covariates are balanced across the groups
ggplot(data, aes(x=chatbot, y=previous_visit)) + geom_boxplot()






ggplot(data, aes(x=chatbot, fill=mobile_device)) + geom_bar(position="fill")






# Run a regression to find the effect of chatbot on sales
model <- lm(purchase_amount ~ chatbot, data=data)
print(summary(model))

#> 
#> Call:
#> lm(formula = purchase_amount ~ chatbot, data = data)
#> 
#> Residuals:
#>     Min      1Q  Median      3Q     Max 
#> -16.702 -14.478  -9.626  13.922  64.648 
#> 
#> Coefficients:
#>             Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)    
#> (Intercept)  16.7017     0.8374  19.944  < 2e-16 ***
#> chatbotTRUE  -7.0756     1.1796  -5.998 2.79e-09 ***
#> ---
#> Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1
#> 
#> Residual standard error: 18.65 on 998 degrees of freedom
#> Multiple R-squared:  0.0348, Adjusted R-squared:  0.03383 
#> F-statistic: 35.98 on 1 and 998 DF,  p-value: 2.787e-09

# Find subgroup-specific effects
model_interaction <- lm(purchase_amount ~ chatbot*mobile_device, data=data)
print(summary(model_interaction))

#> 
#> Call:
#> lm(formula = purchase_amount ~ chatbot * mobile_device, data = data)
#> 
#> Residuals:
#>    Min     1Q Median     3Q    Max 
#> -16.98 -14.54  -9.95  14.13  65.24 
#> 
#> Coefficients:
#>                               Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)    
#> (Intercept)                    16.9797     1.0152  16.725   <2e-16 ***
#> chatbotTRUE                    -7.0301     1.4284  -4.922    1e-06 ***
#> mobile_deviceTRUE              -0.8727     1.7987  -0.485    0.628    
#> chatbotTRUE:mobile_deviceTRUE  -0.1526     2.5369  -0.060    0.952    
#> ---
#> Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1
#> 
#> Residual standard error: 18.66 on 996 degrees of freedom
#> Multiple R-squared:  0.03534,    Adjusted R-squared:  0.03244 
#> F-statistic: 12.16 on 3 and 996 DF,  p-value: 8.034e-08

# Compute a CATE for one exemplary group
# For example, for mobile users
mobile_users <- subset(data, mobile_device == TRUE)
model_mobile <- lm(purchase_amount ~ chatbot, data=mobile_users)
cate_mobile <- coef(summary(model_mobile))
print(cate_mobile)

#>              Estimate Std. Error   t value     Pr(>|t|)
#> (Intercept) 16.107009   1.498155 10.751227 3.575812e-23
#> chatbotTRUE -7.182663   2.115378 -3.395452 7.728973e-04

# Use logistic regression with purchase as outcome variable
model_logistic <- glm(purchase ~ chatbot, data=data, family=binomial(link='logit'))
print(summary(model_logistic))

#> 
#> Call:
#> glm(formula = purchase ~ chatbot, family = binomial(link = "logit"), 
#>     data = data)
#> 
#> Deviance Residuals: 
#>     Min       1Q   Median       3Q      Max  
#> -1.1706  -0.8849  -0.7897   1.1843   1.6232  
#> 
#> Coefficients:
#>             Estimate Std. Error z value Pr(>|z|)    
#> (Intercept) -0.01613    0.08981  -0.180    0.857    
#> chatbotTRUE -0.98939    0.13484  -7.337 2.18e-13 ***
#> ---
#> Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1
#> 
#> (Dispersion parameter for binomial family taken to be 1)
#> 
#>     Null deviance: 1329.1  on 999  degrees of freedom
#> Residual deviance: 1273.3  on 998  degrees of freedom
#> AIC: 1277.3
#> 
#> Number of Fisher Scoring iterations: 4

# Interpret the coefficient for chatbot
chatbot_coef <- coef(model_logistic)
odds_ratio <- exp(chatbot_coef)
print(paste("The odds ratio for chatbot is", odds_ratio, ". This means that for each unit increase in chatbot, the odds of purchase increase by a factor of", odds_ratio, "."))

#> [1] "The odds ratio for chatbot is 0.983999999999998 . This means that for each unit increase in chatbot, the odds of purchase increase by a factor of 0.983999999999998 ."
#> [2] "The odds ratio for chatbot is 0.371802498513822 . This means that for each unit increase in chatbot, the odds of purchase increase by a factor of 0.371802498513822 ."

title: Difference-in-Differences
text:
Note



ok edit comment



data <- readRDS("C:/Users/sophi/OneDrive/Desktop/Causal Data Science for Business Analytics 2023/gitclone/cdsba-swynona/assets/Causal_Data_Science_Data/hospdd.rds")

library(dplyr)

#> Warning: package 'dplyr' was built under R version 4.2.3


#> 
#> Attaching package: 'dplyr'


#> The following objects are masked from 'package:stats':
#> 
#>     filter, lag


#> The following objects are masked from 'package:base':
#> 
#>     intersect, setdiff, setequal, union

# Assuming 'procedure' is a binary variable indicating whether the hospital introduced the new procedure
# and 'month' is a binary variable indicating before (0) and after (1) the introduction
# and 'satis' is the patient satisfaction score

mean_before_treatment <- data %>%
  filter(procedure == 1, month <= 6) %>%
  pull(satis) %>%
  mean()

mean_after_treatment <- data %>%
  filter(procedure == 1, month > 6) %>%
  pull(satis) %>%
  mean()

mean_before_control <- data %>%
  filter(procedure == 0, month <= 6) %>%
  pull(satis) %>%
  mean()

mean_after_control <- data %>%
  filter(procedure == 0, month > 6) %>%
  pull(satis) %>%
  mean()

# Assuming 'hospital' is a factor variable indicating the hospital id
# and 'month' is a factor variable indicating the month of the survey

model1 <- lm(satis ~ procedure * month + month + hospital, data = data)
summary(model1)

#> 
#> Call:
#> lm(formula = satis ~ procedure * month + month + hospital, data = data)
#> 
#> Residuals:
#>     Min      1Q  Median      3Q     Max 
#> -3.3319 -0.6546 -0.0917  0.5549  5.3541 
#> 
#> Coefficients:
#>                  Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)    
#> (Intercept)      3.540037   0.031548 112.211  < 2e-16 ***
#> procedure        0.812977   0.128855   6.309 2.97e-10 ***
#> month           -0.006094   0.006668  -0.914 0.360741    
#> hospital        -0.003673   0.001048  -3.506 0.000458 ***
#> procedure:month  0.013968   0.023445   0.596 0.551329    
#> ---
#> Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1
#> 
#> Residual standard error: 0.9836 on 7363 degrees of freedom
#> Multiple R-squared:  0.1325, Adjusted R-squared:  0.132 
#> F-statistic: 281.1 on 4 and 7363 DF,  p-value: < 2.2e-16

model2 <- lm(satis ~ procedure * month + as.factor(month) + as.factor(hospital), data = data)
summary(model2)

title: Probability Theory
text:
Note



Assignment I on Probability Theory - final submission



1 Assignment 1 - Solution

# Given Probabilities
p_S = 0.3 # probability of having a change in scope
p_S_prime = 0.7 # probability of having no change in scope
p_T_given_S = 0.2 # probability of being on time given a change in scope
p_T_prime_given_S = 0.8 # probability of not being on time given a change in scope
p_T_given_S_prime = 0.6 # probability of being on time given no change in scope
p_T_prime_given_S_prime = 0.4 # probability of not being on time given no change in scope

#intersection probabilities
p_T_and_S = p_S * p_T_given_S
p_T_and_S_prime = p_S_prime * p_T_given_S_prime
p_T_prime_and_S = p_S * p_T_prime_given_S
p_T_prime_and_S_prime = p_S_prime * p_T_prime_given_S_prime

#results
cat("P(T ∩ S) = ", p_T_and_S, "\n")

#> P(T ∩ S) =  0.06

cat("P(T ∩ S') = ", p_T_and_S_prime, "\n")

#> P(T ∩ S') =  0.42

cat("P(T' ∩ S) = ", p_T_prime_and_S, "\n")

#> P(T' ∩ S) =  0.24

cat("P(T' ∩ S') = ", p_T_prime_and_S_prime, "\n")

#> P(T' ∩ S') =  0.28

#sum of all four probabilities
sum_prob = p_T_and_S + p_T_and_S_prime + p_T_prime_and_S + p_T_prime_and_S_prime
cat("The sum of all four probabilities = ", sum_prob, "\n")

#> The sum of all four probabilities =  1



2 Assignment 2 - Solution

# What is the percentage of customers using all three devices?
percentage_all_three_devices <- 0.5

# What is the percentage of customers using at least two devices?
percentage_at_least_two_devices <- 7.3 + 3.3 + 8.8 + 0.5

# What is the percentage of customers using only one device?
percentage_only_one_device <- 42.3 + 27.8 + 10

# Print the answers
print(paste("Percentage of customers using all three devices: ", percentage_all_three_devices, "%"))

#> [1] "Percentage of customers using all three devices:  0.5 %"

print(paste("Percentage of customers using at least two devices: ", percentage_at_least_two_devices, "%"))

#> [1] "Percentage of customers using at least two devices:  19.9 %"

print(paste("Percentage of customers using only one device: ", percentage_only_one_device, "%"))

#> [1] "Percentage of customers using only one device:  80.1 %"



3 Assignment 3 - Solution

# Known probabilities
P_B_given_A <- 0.97
P_B_given_not_A <- 0.01
P_A <- 0.04

# Compute P(not A)
P_not_A <- 1 - P_A

# Compute P(B)
P_B <- P_B_given_A * P_A + P_B_given_not_A * P_not_A

# Compute P(A|B) and P(not A|B)
P_A_given_B <- (P_B_given_A * P_A) / P_B
P_not_A_given_B <- (P_B_given_not_A * P_not_A) / P_B

# Print the results
print(paste("P(A|B) =", P_A_given_B))

#> [1] "P(A|B) = 0.801652892561983"

print(paste("P(not A|B) =", P_not_A_given_B))

#> [1] "P(not A|B) = 0.198347107438017"

title: Regression and Statistical Inference
text:
Note



You can delete everything in here and start fresh.



#install.packages("tidyverse")
library(tidyverse)

#> ✖ dplyr::filter() masks stats::filter()
#> ✖ dplyr::lag()    masks stats::lag()
#> ℹ Use the conflicted package (<http://conflicted.r-lib.org/>) to force all conflicts to become errors

data <- readRDS("C:/Users/sophi/OneDrive/Desktop/Causal Data Science for Business Analytics 2023/gitclone/cdsba-swynona/assets/Causal_Data_Science_Data/car_prices.rds")
print(dim(data))

#> [1] 181  22

str(data)

#> tibble [181 × 22] (S3: tbl_df/tbl/data.frame)
#>  $ aspiration      : chr [1:181] "std" "std" "std" "std" ...
#>  $ doornumber      : chr [1:181] "two" "two" "two" "four" ...
#>  $ carbody         : chr [1:181] "convertible" "convertible" "hatchback" "sedan" ...
#>  $ drivewheel      : chr [1:181] "rwd" "rwd" "rwd" "fwd" ...
#>  $ enginelocation  : chr [1:181] "front" "front" "front" "front" ...
#>  $ wheelbase       : num [1:181] 88.6 88.6 94.5 99.8 99.4 ...
#>  $ carlength       : num [1:181] 169 169 171 177 177 ...
#>  $ carwidth        : num [1:181] 64.1 64.1 65.5 66.2 66.4 66.3 71.4 71.4 71.4 67.9 ...
#>  $ carheight       : num [1:181] 48.8 48.8 52.4 54.3 54.3 53.1 55.7 55.7 55.9 52 ...
#>  $ curbweight      : num [1:181] 2548 2548 2823 2337 2824 ...
#>  $ enginetype      : chr [1:181] "dohc" "dohc" "ohcv" "ohc" ...
#>  $ cylindernumber  : chr [1:181] "four" "four" "six" "four" ...
#>  $ enginesize      : num [1:181] 130 130 152 109 136 136 136 136 131 131 ...
#>  $ fuelsystem      : chr [1:181] "mpfi" "mpfi" "mpfi" "mpfi" ...
#>  $ boreratio       : num [1:181] 3.47 3.47 2.68 3.19 3.19 3.19 3.19 3.19 3.13 3.13 ...
#>  $ stroke          : num [1:181] 2.68 2.68 3.47 3.4 3.4 3.4 3.4 3.4 3.4 3.4 ...
#>  $ compressionratio: num [1:181] 9 9 9 10 8 8.5 8.5 8.5 8.3 7 ...
#>  $ horsepower      : num [1:181] 111 111 154 102 115 110 110 110 140 160 ...
#>  $ peakrpm         : num [1:181] 5000 5000 5000 5500 5500 5500 5500 5500 5500 5500 ...
#>  $ citympg         : num [1:181] 21 21 19 24 18 19 19 19 17 16 ...
#>  $ highwaympg      : num [1:181] 27 27 26 30 22 25 25 25 20 22 ...
#>  $ price           : num [1:181] 13495 16500 16500 13950 17450 ...

#assume 'price' is the dependent variable and all other variables are independent
model <- lm(price ~ ., data = data)
summary(model)

#> 
#> Call:
#> lm(formula = price ~ ., data = data)
#> 
#> Residuals:
#>    Min     1Q Median     3Q    Max

#>

# Let's choose 'horsepower' as the regressor
horsepower <- data$horsepower
print(typeof(horsepower))

#> [1] "double"

print(range(horsepower))

#> [1]  48 288

# The coefficient of 'horsepower' in the model gives us the effect on price
coef(model)["horsepower"]

#> horsepower 
#>   10.29354

# The p-value of 'horsepower' in the model tells us about its statistical significance
summary(model)$coefficients["horsepower", "Pr(>|t|)"]

#> [1] 0.6510351

data <- data %>% mutate(seat_heating = TRUE)

# Run a regression with the new variable
model_with_seat_heating <- lm(price ~ ., data = data)
summary(model_with_seat_heating)

title: Regression Discontinuity
text:
Note



You can delete everything in here and start fresh.
